event.title: 1907; Temple De Hirsch Sinai on the opposite corner of the same block is a successor to that congregation; the original Temple De Hirsch is largely demolished

data.event: Jewish residents built Temple De Hirsch on Union Street in 1907; Temple De Hirsch Sinai on the opposite corner of the same block is a successor to that congregation; the original Temple De Hirsch is largely demolished, though some fragments remain.

event.title: A few decades later, the Central District became

data.event: A few decades later, the Central District became a home to Japanese-Americans in Seattle.
By the 1970s, Central District became largely an African-American neighborhood and the center of the civil rights movement in Seattle.
In 1970, Blacks made up nearly 80% of the neighborhood's population [1] However, it also marked the neighborhood's decline into poverty and crime for another two decades.

event.title: poverty and crime for another two decades
